entry.title: Re: Check data and specify void reason code INTERCOMPANY...
entry.content:
Maybe this could help in your analysis : 

 

Troubleshooting: FBU8 Cross-Company Code Document Reversal - Missing Checkbox for Company Code 1100

Symptom

  • Error Message: "Check data and specify void reason code" during document reversal in PRD environment
  • Missing Element: Checkbox not available for company code 1100 in FBU8 reversal screen
  • Environment: Issue occurs in Production (PRD) but not in Quality Assurance (QAS)
  • Transaction Code: FBU8 (Reverse Cross-Company Code Document)
  • Document Type: Cross-company code document involving company code 1100

Current Configuration Status

Verified Settings
  • Void/Reversal Reasons: Properly configured in FBU8
  • Posting Periods: Open for all relevant company codes
  • QAS Environment: Same document reverses successfully with identical configuration
System Behavior Differences
Environment Reversal Status Checkbox Availability Error Message
QASSuccessfulAvailable for all company codesNone
PRDFailedMissing for company code 1100Check data and specify void reason code

Possible Root Causes

Configuration-Related Causes

  1. Company Code-Specific Settings

    • Reversal authorization differences between PRD and QAS for company code 1100
    • Document type restrictions in PRD environment
    • Posting period variants specific to company code 1100

  2. User Authorization Issues

    • Missing authorization objects for company code 1100 in PRD
    • Role differences between PRD and QAS environments
    • Activity-specific permissions for document reversal

  3. System Configuration Discrepancies

    • Transport issues causing configuration differences
    • Manual configuration changes not replicated from QAS to PRD
    • Environment-specific customization settings
Technical Causes

  1. Document Status Issues [1]

    • Document already partially processed or locked
    • Clearing status preventing reversal - documents with cleared items cannot be reversed until clearing is reset
    • Workflow or approval process blocking reversal

  2. Cross-Company Transaction Constraints [2]

    • One or more company documents within the inter-company transaction cannot be reversed
    • Period closure for specific company codes
    • Documents originated from other modules (SD, MM) requiring module-specific reversal

Diagnostic Steps

Step 1: Authorization Verification

  1. Check User Authorizations

    • Verify authorization object F_BKPF_BUK for company code 1100
    • Validate activity 02 (Change) permissions
    • Compare user roles between PRD and QAS
    • Run SU53 immediately after the error to check authorization failures

  2. Transaction-Specific Authorizations

    • Review FBU8-specific authorization requirements
    • Check authorization object F_BKPF_GSB for business area restrictions
    • Validate document type authorization (F_BKPF_BLA)
Step 2: Document Status Analysis

  1. Clearing Status Check [1]

    • Use FB03 to display the document and check for cleared items
    • Look for clearing document numbers and dates in line items
    • If cleared items exist, use FBRA to reset clearing before attempting reversal

  2. Cross-Company Document Validation [2]

    • Verify all company codes involved in the cross-company transaction
    • Check if any individual company code documents have restrictions
    • Confirm posting periods are open for all involved company codes
Step 3: Configuration Comparison

  1. Company Code Settings

    • Compare company code 1100 configuration between PRD and QAS using OX02
    • Verify fiscal year variant and posting period variant settings
    • Check currency and valuation settings

  2. Document Type Configuration

    • Review document type settings in OBA7
    • Verify reversal document type assignments
    • Check number range assignments and availability

Resolution Steps

Immediate Actions

  1. Clear Document Issues [1]

    • If document contains cleared items, use FBRA to reset clearing first
    • Check for any document locks using SM12 and release if necessary
    • Verify document hasn't been processed by other modules

  2. Authorization Resolution

    • Grant missing authorizations for company code 1100 if identified
    • Copy successful user profile from QAS to PRD if applicable
    • Request authorization administrator to review and update user roles

  3. Period and Status Verification [2]

    • Ensure posting periods are open for all company codes in the cross-company transaction
    • Verify no period-end closing activities are blocking the reversal
    • Check if documents originated from FI or other modules
Advanced Troubleshooting

  1. System Analysis

    • Review system logs (SM21) for detailed error information
    • Check application logs in SLG1 for FI-related messages
    • Use transaction FB03 to analyze the complete document structure

  2. Alternative Reversal Methods [3],

    • Consider using the "Reverse Journal Entries (Cross-Company Code)" Fiori app if available
    • For S/4HANA Cloud, ensure you're using the correct reversal application [4]
    • Verify if the document can be reversed through individual company code reversals

Validation Checklist

  • Authorization verification completed for company code 1100
  • Document clearing status checked and reset if necessary
  • All company codes in cross-company transaction verified
  • Posting periods confirmed open for all involved company codes
  • System logs analyzed for detailed error messages
  • Document origin (FI vs other modules) confirmed
  • Test reversal performed after implementing fixes

Preventive Measures

  1. Regular Configuration Audits

    • Schedule periodic comparison of critical configuration between environments
    • Implement automated transport monitoring for FI configuration changes
    • Establish change management process for company code settings

  2. Authorization Management

    • Create standardized authorization roles for document reversal activities
    • Implement regular authorization reviews and updates
    • Document authorization requirements for cross-company transactions

  3. Document Management

    • Establish procedures for handling cleared documents before reversal
    • Create guidelines for cross-company document reversal processes
    • Implement monitoring for period-end activities affecting reversals

Expected Resolution Timeline

  • Immediate (0-2 hours): Authorization and document status checks
  • Short-term (2-8 hours): Configuration synchronization and clearing reset
  • Medium-term (1-2 days): Complex debugging and system analysis if needed

entry.title: Re: SAP B1 HANA v10 FP2502â€“ Blank Screen and Unresponsive...
entry.content:
Maybe this will help in your analysis :

 

Troubleshooting: SAP Business One HANA v10 FP2502 Blank Screen Issue After Re-login

Symptom

  • Application Version: SAP Business One HANA v10 FP2502
  • Issue Description: Application gets stuck on blank (white) screen after re-login with unresponsive interface
  • Frequency: Random occurrence, not every login attempt
  • User Impact: Multiple users experiencing the issue intermittently
  • Screen Dependency: Issue occurs across different screens, not tied to specific documents or forms

Current Troubleshooting Status

Actions Already Taken
  • UI Cache Clearing:
    • Path: C:\Users\\AppData\Local\SAP\SAP Business One\
    • Action: Deleted Cache folder and restarted application
    • Result: Issue persists despite cache clearing
Issue Characteristics
Aspect Details
TriggerRe-login action
Screen StateBlank/white screen with no UI elements
User InteractionComplete unresponsiveness to clicks
Occurrence PatternRandom/intermittent across multiple users
Document DependencyNot tied to specific documents or screens

Possible Root Causes

Client-Side Issues

  1. Display and Graphics

    • Graphics driver compatibility issues with SAP Business One UI framework
    • Display scaling/resolution conflicts causing UI rendering problems
    • Hardware acceleration conflicts with application graphics components

  2. Application Components

    • Corrupted application files or registry entries affecting UI initialization
    • Memory allocation issues during session initialization process
    • UI framework conflicts or missing dependencies

  3. System Resources

    • Insufficient memory or CPU resources during login process
    • Conflicting background processes interfering with application startup
    • Antivirus interference with application components or file access
Server-Side Issues

  1. HANA Database Connection

    • Connection pool exhaustion preventing proper session establishment
    • Database lock or timeout issues during user authentication
    • HANA service interruptions affecting client connectivity

  2. License Server

    • License server communication problems during session validation [1]
    • Session management conflicts with concurrent users
    • License allocation issues preventing proper application initialization

  3. Application Server

    • Server resource constraints affecting client session handling
    • Session handling problems in multi-user environments
    • Service interruptions or restarts during critical login phases

Diagnostic Steps

Step 1: Client Environment Analysis

  1. System Requirements Verification

    • Check minimum system requirements compliance for v10 FP2502
    • Verify Windows version compatibility and latest updates
    • Validate .NET Framework version and dependencies

  2. Graphics and Display Settings

    • Update graphics drivers to latest certified version
    • Test with different display scaling settings (100%, 125%, 150%)
    • Disable hardware acceleration temporarily in display settings

  3. Application Integrity Check

    • Run SAP Business One repair installation from Control Panel
    • Check Windows Event Viewer for application errors during login attempts
    • Verify all SAP Business One services are running (License Manager, SLD)
Step 2: Advanced Cache and Registry Cleanup

  1. Extended Cache Clearing

    • Clear additional cache locations:
      • %TEMP%\SAP Business One\
      • %APPDATA%\SAP\SAP Business One\
      • %LOCALAPPDATA%\SAP\SAP Business One\Cache\
    • Remove temporary files and application-specific folders
    • Clear browser cache if web-based components are integrated

  2. Registry Cleanup

    • Backup and clean SAP Business One registry entries under:
      • HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\SAP\SAP Business One
      • HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\SAP\SAP Business One
    • Remove orphaned registry keys from previous installations
    • Reset user-specific application settings to defaults

  3. Profile Reset

    • Create new Windows user profile for testing purposes
    • Reset SAP Business One user preferences and customizations
    • Test with minimal user customizations and default settings
Step 3: Network and Connectivity Testing

  1. Database Connection Testing

    • Test HANA database connectivity using HANA Studio or SAP HANA Cockpit
    • Monitor connection stability during login process using network tools
    • Check for network timeouts or interruptions in connection logs

  2. License Server Verification

    • Verify license server accessibility and response times
    • Check license allocation and availability for affected users
    • Monitor license server logs during issue occurrence for errors

Resolution Steps

Immediate Actions

  1. Client-Side Fixes

    • Update graphics drivers to latest version and disable hardware acceleration
    • Run SAP Business One application as administrator
    • Temporarily disable antivirus real-time scanning during testing
    • Set Windows compatibility mode to Windows 8 or earlier if needed

  2. Application Repair

    • Perform SAP Business One repair installation through Windows Programs
    • Re-register application components using regsvr32 for SAP DLLs
    • Reset application to factory default settings
    • Reinstall Visual C++ Redistributables if corrupted

  3. Alternative Login Methods

    • Test with different user accounts to isolate user-specific issues
    • Try logging in from different workstations to identify machine-specific problems
    • Use CTRL+SHIFT during login to bypass add-ons if installed
    • Test with minimal system startup (Safe Mode with Networking)
Advanced Troubleshooting

  1. System Analysis

    • Monitor system resources (CPU, Memory, Disk I/O) during login process
    • Check Windows Event Logs for critical errors or warnings
    • Use Process Monitor (ProcMon) to track file/registry access patterns
    • Analyze application crash dumps if generated

  2. Network Diagnostics

    • Test network connectivity to HANA server using telnet or ping
    • Monitor network traffic during login using Wireshark or similar tools
    • Check firewall and proxy settings for blocked connections
    • Verify DNS resolution for server hostnames

  3. Database Investigation

    • Review HANA database logs for connection errors or timeouts
    • Check for blocking processes or locks during user login attempts
    • Monitor database performance metrics during login process
    • Verify database user permissions and authentication settings

Known Issues and SAP Notes

Based on similar reported issues, consider reviewing these SAP Notes:

  • SAP Note 3274346: Related to blank screen issues in SAP Business One [1]
  • SAP Note 3505438: Double login requirement with Fiori-style cockpit [2]
  • SAP Note 3573548: Client crashes during login process [3]
  • SAP Note 3424945: Performance issues after minimizing client [4]

Validation Steps

  • Graphics driver updated and hardware acceleration tested
  • Application repair completed successfully
  • Extended cache clearing performed across all locations
  • Registry cleanup completed with proper backup
  • Network connectivity to HANA server verified
  • License server accessibility confirmed
  • Alternative user profiles tested
  • System logs analyzed for error patterns
  • Add-on bypass testing completed
  • Compatibility mode testing performed

Preventive Measures

  1. Regular Maintenance

    • Schedule periodic cache clearing across all client machines
    • Implement regular system updates and SAP Business One patches
    • Monitor system resource usage and set up alerts for thresholds
    • Establish regular graphics driver update schedules

  2. Environment Standardization

    • Standardize client configurations across all user workstations
    • Implement consistent graphics driver versions organization-wide
    • Establish and document baseline system requirements
    • Create standard operating procedures for client setup

  3. Monitoring Implementation

    • Set up application performance monitoring for login processes
    • Implement automated health checks for critical system components
    • Create alerting for system resource thresholds and connectivity issues
    • Monitor license server performance and availability

Escalation Criteria

  • SAP Support: If issue persists after comprehensive client-side troubleshooting
  • System Administrator: For server-side investigation and database analysis
  • Network Team: If connectivity issues are suspected or confirmed
  • Hardware Vendor: For graphics or hardware-related compatibility problems

Additional Resources

  • SAP Business One System Requirements documentation for v10 FP2502
  • SAP Knowledge Base articles for version-specific blank screen issues
  • HANA database troubleshooting and connectivity guides
  • Graphics driver compatibility matrices for business applications
  1.

entry.title: Re: allocate line item on sow to more than 1 cost center
entry.content:
Maybe this will help in your analysis :

 

How to Allocate SOW Line Item to Multiple Cost Centers

Overview

Multiple cost center allocation for SOW line items enables organizations to distribute costs across different departments or business units based on actual usage, shared services, or project requirements. This functionality is essential for accurate cost accounting and budget management when services or deliverables benefit multiple organizational units.

Current System Behavior

Standard Allocation Process

In SAP Fieldglass, SOW line items are typically assigned to a single cost center during initial creation. However, the system supports multiple cost center allocation through cost allocation editing functionality, which allows splitting line item costs across multiple cost centers using either percentage-based or amount-based distribution methods [1].

Timing Constraints
SOW Status Allocation Method Limitations
Draft/PendingInitial setup during creationLimited to configured cost centers
ApprovedEdit Cost Allocation via Actions menuRequires proper user permissions
ActiveStandard editing processMay require approval workflow

Pre-Approval Allocation Methods

Method 1: Initial SOW Setup with Segmented Object Detail
  1. Enable Segmented Object Detail Configuration: Ensure the company configuration "Segmented object detail based allocation is required" is enabled [2]
  2. Create Segmented Object Detail (SOD): Navigate to Admin Page > Segmented Object Detail > click New, select Type as "Segmented Object Detail"
  3. Associate SOD to Cost Centers: On the SOD Details page, click Cost Centers tab > Add > select multiple cost centers and associate them with the SOD [2]
  4. Configure Line Item Allocation: During SOW creation, use the SOD functionality to define multiple cost center allocations before submission
Method 2: Line Item Configuration During SOW Creation
  1. Access Line Item Details: During SOW drafting, navigate to the line item configuration section
  2. Configure Cost Center Split: Add multiple cost centers to the line item using the cost allocation interface
  3. Set Distribution Method: Choose between percentage-based or amount-based allocation [1]
  4. Validate Allocation Totals: Ensure total allocation equals 100% for percentage-based or matches line item amount for amount-based allocation [3]
Method 3: Template-Based Approach
  1. Create SOW Template: Develop standardized SOW templates with pre-configured multiple cost center allocations
  2. Apply Template: Use the template during SOW creation to automatically populate cost center splits
  3. Customize Allocations: Modify allocation percentages or amounts based on specific project requirements
  4. Submit for Approval: Complete the SOW submission process with configured multi-cost center allocations

Post-Approval Allocation Process

Standard Editing Method
  1. Navigate to Approved SOW: Access the SOW from your dashboard or search functionality
  2. Access Actions Menu: Select the Actions menu from the SOW line item's Details page [1]
  3. Select Edit Cost Allocation: Choose "Edit Cost Allocation" from the available options
  4. Configure Multiple Cost Centers: In the Edit Cost Allocation modal, add additional cost centers and define their allocation shares
  5. Choose Allocation Method: Select either "Percentage" or "Amount" under "Show Cost Allocation By" [1]
  6. Calculate and Update: Use the "Calculate Totals" button to verify allocations, then select "Update" to save changes [1]
Allocation Rules
  • Percentage-based allocation: Total percentages must equal 100.000% [3]
  • Amount-based allocation: Total allocated amounts must equal the line item amount
  • Validation requirements: System displays totals in red if allocation doesn't meet requirements [1]

Configuration Requirements

System Prerequisites
  • User Permissions: Users must have access to allocate invoices and cost allocation functionality [4]
  • Cost Center Master Data: All target cost centers must be properly configured and active in the system
  • Company Configuration: Enable relevant cost allocation settings and segmented object detail functionality if required [2]
Business Rules
  • SOW Status Requirements: SOW or SOW Revision must be in Approved status, with line items in Pending Approval status [3]
  • Task Code Configuration: If Task Code related company configuration is enabled, each cost center can have only one task code [3]
  • Allocation Overwrite: When uploaded, cost allocations for SOW line items will completely overwrite existing allocations

Alternative Solutions

Workaround 1: Multiple Line Items
  • Create Separate Line Items: Instead of one line item with multiple cost centers, create individual line items for each cost center
  • Single Cost Center Assignment: Assign one cost center per line item to achieve the desired cost distribution
  • Maintain Service Consistency: Use identical service descriptions and deliverable details across related line items
Workaround 2: Manual Reallocation
  • Post-Invoice Processing: Allow initial posting to single cost center, then perform manual cost reallocation
  • Finance Team Coordination: Work with finance team to create journal entries redistributing costs
  • Documentation Requirements: Maintain clear audit trail for cost reallocation decisions
Workaround 3: Upload-Based Allocation
  • Bulk Upload Process: Use the SOW Line Item Approval Cost Center Allocation Upload functionality for multiple line items [3]
  • Template Preparation: Prepare allocation data in the required format with cost center and allocation details
  • Validation and Processing: Ensure all validation requirements are met before upload processing

Best Practices

  • Pre-Planning Strategy: Define cost allocation strategy and obtain stakeholder approval before SOW creation
  • Documentation Standards: Maintain clear business justification for cost splits and allocation methodologies
  • Finance Coordination: Collaborate with finance team to ensure allocation methods align with accounting standards
  • Regular Review Process: Implement periodic reviews of allocation accuracy and business relevance

Troubleshooting Common Issues

Issue 1: Allocation Percentage Errors
  • Symptom: System displays red totals indicating allocation doesn't equal 100%
  • Resolution: Use "Calculate Totals" button and adjust percentages to ensure exact 100% total [1]
Issue 2: Cost Center Validation Failures
  • Common Causes: Inactive cost centers, incorrect cost center codes, or missing task code assignments
  • Correction Procedures: Verify cost center master data and ensure all target cost centers are active and properly configured
Issue 3: Missing Edit Cost Allocation Option
  • Root Cause: Rule "Add and Remove Cost Objects while editing line item cost allocation on an approved SOW" may be disabled [5] [6]
  • Resolution: Enable parent rule "Allow Buyer to edit Line Item Cost Allocation when Buyer adds Line Item to Statement of Work" first

Configuration Dependencies

  • Parent Rule Requirement: The rule "Add and Remove Cost Objects while editing line item cost allocation on an approved Statement of Work" depends on the parent rule "Allow Buyer to edit Line Item Cost Allocation when Buyer adds Line Item to Statement of Work" being enabled [5]
  • Cost Center Propagation: Be aware that the company configuration "Propagate Statement of Work Cost Centers to SOW Line Items in Created Status" may overwrite line item allocations with SOW-level allocations [7]

Related Documentation

  • SAP Fieldglass Help Portal: Editing Cost Allocation on Line Items
  • SAP Knowledge Base Article 3659532: How to associate multiple cost centers on SOW line items [8] [2]
  • SAP Knowledge Base Article 3304252: SOW Line Item cost center allocation overwrite scenarios [9] [7]

entry.title: Re: Personas: How to display each employee's picture?
entry.content:
Please check if this may help you:

 

SAP Screen Personas: Employee Picture Display Configuration

Requirement Overview

  • Objective: Display employee pictures in transaction PA30 using Screen Personas
  • Transaction Code: PA30 - Maintain HR Master Data
  • Technology: SAP Screen Personas
  • Business Need: Visual identification of employees in HR transactions

Technical Feasibility Assessment

Question 1: Dynamic Image Display by Employee Number

Capability: Yes - it is possible to attach different images based on employee number

Implementation Approach:

  • Method 1: Dynamic image binding using Screen Personas scripting with employee number field binding
  • Method 2: Conditional image display through JavaScript/SAPUI5 controls with path construction logic
  • Method 3: Script-based image switching leveraging Screen Personas flavor customization capabilities [1]

Technical Requirements:

  • Screen Personas 3.0 or higher for advanced scripting capabilities
  • Image format specifications: .png, .jpg, .jpeg, .gif supported formats [1]
  • Performance considerations for image loading and caching
Question 2: Image Storage Location Options
Storage Option Advantages Disadvantages Implementation Complexity
File ServerDirect file access, simple naming convention, easy bulk managementNetwork dependency, security concerns, path managementMedium
SAP Office DocumentsIntegrated with SAP, standard attachment functionality, audit trailLimited bulk operations, version management complexityLow
Content Server/ArchiveLinkEnterprise-grade storage, integrated with HR, standard SAP functionalityRequires ArchiveLink configuration, higher setup complexityHigh

Implementation Methods

Method 1: File Server Storage Approach

  1. File Structure Setup

    • Create directory structure: /images/employees/[PERNR]/photo.[ext]
    • Naming convention: Use personnel number as primary identifier
    • File format specifications: JPG/PNG format, maximum 2MB file size, recommended dimensions 150x200 pixels

  2. Screen Personas Configuration

    • Add image control to PA30 screen using Personas Editor
    • Configure dynamic path using Javascript: "/images/employees/" + employeeNumber + "/photo.jpg"
    • Implement employee number field binding through screen field references

  3. Security Considerations

    • Configure file server access permissions for SAP application server
    • Set up network path accessibility from SAP system
    • Implement user authorization checks for image viewing
Method 2: SAP Office Document Integration

  1. Document Management Setup

    • Configure SAP Office document services and attachment functionality
    • Define document type 'HRICOLFOTO' for employee photos [2],[3]
    • Link attachments to personnel numbers using business object 'PREL' ,

  2. Personas Integration

    • Implement document retrieval using standard SAP attachment services
    • Configure image display component in Personas flavor
    • Create dynamic document linking based on personnel number

  3. Maintenance Procedures

    • Use transaction OAAD for image upload and assignment [2],[3]
    • Implement document versioning through standard SAP functionality
    • Enable bulk upload through ArchiveLink batch processing

Configuration Steps

Step 1: Screen Personas Flavor Creation

  1. Access PA30 Transaction

    • Navigate to PA30 and identify optimal screen area for employee image display
    • Consider screen real estate and user workflow impact

  2. Create New Flavor

    • Use transaction /n/personas/resources for image resource management [1]
    • Create flavor with naming convention: PA30_EMPLOYEE_PHOTO_V1
    • Assign to target user groups or roles

  3. Add Image Control

    • Insert image display element in Personas Editor
    • Configure size (recommended 150x200 pixels) and positioning
    • Set image properties for dynamic loading and error handling
Step 2: Dynamic Image Binding

  1. Script Development

    • Implement JavaScript for dynamic image loading based on personnel number
    • Create employee number field binding using screen field references
    • Add error handling for missing images with fallback to default placeholder

  2. Path Configuration

    • Construct dynamic path: var imagePath = "/images/employees/" + pernr + "/photo.jpg";
    • Implement file naming pattern validation
    • Configure fallback image for employees without photos

  3. Testing and Validation

    • Test with multiple employee numbers across different scenarios
    • Verify image loading performance and response times
    • Validate error handling when images are missing or inaccessible
Step 3: Image Management Process

  1. Image Standards

    • File formats: JPG, PNG (recommended JPG for smaller file sizes)
    • Image dimensions: 150x200 pixels (portrait orientation)
    • File size limitations: Maximum 2MB per image

  2. Upload Procedures

    • Manual upload: Use OAAD transaction for individual employee photo upload [2],[3]
    • Batch upload: Implement file server batch copy with naming convention validation
    • Image quality validation through automated checks

  3. Maintenance Workflow

    • New employee: Add photo during onboarding process
    • Image updates: Replace existing files with version control
    • Cleanup: Remove photos for terminated employees per retention policy

Technical Considerations

Performance Optimization
  • Image Caching Strategy: Implement browser-side caching and SAP application server caching
  • Load Time Optimization: Use image compression (80% quality JPG) and lazy loading for off-screen images
  • Network Impact: Optimize image sizes and implement progressive loading
Security and Compliance
  • Data Privacy: Ensure compliance with GDPR and local privacy regulations for employee photos
  • Access Control: Implement authorization checks using standard SAP authorization objects
  • Audit Trail: Log image access and modifications through standard SAP audit functionality
System Integration
  • HR Module Integration: Leverage standard HR function modules like HR_IMAGE_EXISTS, HR_IMAGE_INIT, and HR_IMAGE_SHOW [2]
  • Cross-System Compatibility: Ensure image paths work across development, quality, and production systems
  • Upgrade Compatibility: Test Personas flavors after SAP system upgrades and patches

Alternative Solutions

Option 1: Standard SAP Functionality
  • Attachment Services: Use standard PA30 attachment functionality with document type configuration [4]
  • Document Management: Integrate with SAP Document Management System for enterprise-grade storage
  • Custom Development: Create ABAP module pool program with custom container for image display [2]
Option 2: Third-Party Integration
  • External Image Services: Integrate with HR systems or employee directories
  • Cloud Storage: Use cloud-based storage with API integration
  • Mobile Integration: Enable mobile photo capture and upload capabilities

entry.title: Large Cap Biopharma: 2024 Valuation Sensitivities
entry.content:
Pfizer: Valuation as a Reflection of Complexity

Pfizer is often discussed in the market through simplified narratives: post-pandemic normalization, patent expirations, or near-term earnings pressure. While each element matters, none is sufficient by itself to explain Pfizerâ€™s performance, strategic positioning, or valuation.

Earlier this year, we developed a detailed analysis of Pfizer, including a Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) valuation model, to better understand the companyâ€™s potential for long-term value creation. A few months later, it is useful to step back and reflect on that analysis â€” not to revise conclusions, but to place them in a broader business context.

This note follows a bottom-up structure: starting with business and portfolio dynamics, moving through capital allocation and profitability, and only then connecting these elements to valuation and market pricing. While COVID-related effects remain part of the recent financial history, they are not the central driver of the long-term dynamics discussed here.

Pfizer operates one of the most complex business models in global healthcare. Its activities span research-intensive innovation, large-scale manufacturing, regulatory navigation, portfolio lifecycle management, and capital allocation across long time horizons. Even a simple snapshot of Pfizer in Q1 2025 illustrates how many moving parts must work together to sustain performance.

A Business Defined by Scale, Scope, and Long Cycles

Pfizerâ€™s scale is both an advantage and a constraint. A broad portfolio across therapeutic areas and geographies provides diversification, global reach, and operational leverage. At the same time, scale introduces complexity:

  • long development timelines
  • staggered patent cliffs
  • heterogeneous market dynamics
  • continuous reinvestment requirements

Importantly, Pfizer is not a single-product or single-cycle company. Its economic profile reflects the aggregation of many medical solutions at different stages of maturity, each with distinct risk, return, and timing characteristics. As a result, short-term performance is an imperfect proxy for long-term value creation, particularly given long drug investment cycles.

Revenue Is Not a Single Trajectory

One recurring theme from the analysis is that Pfizerâ€™s revenue profile cannot be understood as a linear trend. Revenue is shaped by several overlapping forces:

  • portfolio turnover as products mature and face loss of exclusivity
  • the timing and slope of pipeline launches
  • geographic mix and pricing dynamics
  • external shocks, normalization effects, and inorganic investments

Rather than viewing revenue volatility as a sign of instability, it is more accurate to see it as a structural feature of large-cap biopharma. The portfolio requires constant rebalancing as some drugs experience revenue decline and others take their place. The central question is not whether revenues fluctuate, but whether the organization can consistently replenish its portfolio.

When we zoom in on pre-LOE drugs, some high-revenue products already show signs of slowing or decline, while others continue to grow but approach patent expiration. This naturally raises the question: what happens to biopharma revenues before, during, and after LOE?

The answer depends on a nuanced interplay of internal actions and external factors â€” including lifecycle management strategies, competitive dynamics, and therapeutic alternatives. These factors can mean the difference between a steep revenue drop and a more controlled decline.

 

In practice, a large biopharma company such as Pfizer constantly experiences both growth and decline across its product portfolio.

While some drugs mature and slow down, others pick up and help sustain revenue continuity. In this sense, large biopharma resembles portfolio management: individual assets rise and fall, requiring ongoing reinvestment and reallocation rather than optimization of any single product.

Inorganic Portfolio Balancing

The need for continuous portfolio renewal naturally leads to a strategic choice: invest internally through R&D, or acquire external assets.

 

A review of Pfizerâ€™s mergers, acquisitions, and divestitures shows a willingness to act decisively to maintain portfolio relevance. While the pricing of some acquisitions has been debated, the broader pattern is clear: inorganic actions play a central role in shaping portfolio maturity and future growth potential.

 

Capital Allocation Is Central to the Story

Decisions around internal R&D, acquisitions, divestitures, debt management, and shareholder returns collectively shape Pfizerâ€™s risk profile and future earnings power.

Capital allocation at this scale is not about optimizing a single metric in a single year. It centers on balancing:

  • flexibility
  • resilience
  • long-term value creation

Over the last seven years, Pfizer has invested more than $70 billion through inorganic transactions â€” a magnitude comparable to its organic R&D spending. Beyond acquisition prices and divestiture proceeds, these transactions also carry ongoing costs, including post-merger integration and transition services (TSA).

Criticism around capital deployment often focuses on the argument that value erosion reflects overpayment for acquisitions. In support of this argument, current valuation multiples are often cited as the benchmarks for a fair acquisition consideration.

 

While this perspective deserves consideration, it is incomplete without examining Pfizerâ€™s broader capital structure and working capital dynamics.

 

To fund both organic and inorganic investments â€” while maintaining dividend payments exceeding $9.5 billion in 2024 â€” Pfizer increased leverage. Total debt rose from approximately $35 billion at the beginning of 2023 to $71 billion a year later, before declining to $64 billion at the start of 2025. With equity of roughly $88 billion, the resulting debt-to-equity ratio stood near 72%.

 

Margins Reflect Strategic Choices, Not Just Efficiency

Operating margins can be scrutinized in isolation, but they reflect deliberate trade-offs. Investment in R&D, business development, manufacturing capabilities, tax optimization and commercial infrastructure all weigh on near-term margins while supporting long-term optionality.

 

Periods of margin compression often coincide with pipeline build-out or integration of acquired assets. Margin recovery, in turn, depends on successful execution and maturation of those investments.

Recognizing margin pressure, Pfizer launched a transformation program aimed at cost reduction. Reviewing this program alongside historical performance allows us to outline plausible ranges for future operating efficiency and margin expansion â€” not as guarantees, but as scenarios grounded in past behavior and structural constraints.

Key Model Assumptions

With revenue dynamics, profitability, and capital deployment established, we then turn to the DCF model.

Fully aware of LOE-related revenue risks, we conservatively project revenue growth of 1% per year over the next five years.

This leads to the following free cash flow components used in the valuation.

As a result, the full Free Cash Flow picture can be summarized as follows:

 

Estimating the Weighted Average Cost of Capital involves both financial analysis and judgment. Once WACC is established, we proceed to the full DCF framework, using both perpetuity growth and terminal EBITDA multiple approaches.

With the WACC estimated, we can proceed to the full DCF model which can be conceptually described as follows:

We utilize both Perpetuity Growth and Terminal Value EBITDA Multiple approaches to estimate Pfizerâ€™s Enterprise Value on the basis of the above projected financials.

Valuation as an Output, Not an Assumption

While the resulting enterprise value and implied share price are informative, the sensitivity analysis is more revealing.

Given Pfizerâ€™s transformation efforts following COVID-related normalization, the key question is not whether profitability can improve, but within what range such improvement might plausibly occur â€” and how markets might value that improvement.

We can visualize these plausible scenarios by examining a few parameters that affect enterprise value:

By examining a limited set of parameters that meaningfully affect enterprise value, we can explore scenarios such as:

  • Can Pfizer improve EBIT by 10%?
  • How might such improvement translate into shareholder value?

If operating gains materialize, the model suggests that valuation can respond meaningfully. However, capturing that value requires disciplined execution across all dimensions of the business:

  • portfolio execution with the revenue impact
  • cost discipline for profitability expansion
  • capital allocation including acquisition premium in line with the investor expectations
  • market confidence translating into COE and WACC

Enterprise Value Sensitivity Surface: A Landscape, Not a Point

Not all valuation drivers are within managementâ€™s control. Financial market expectations, interest rates, and macroeconomic conditions add further complexity.

The enterprise value sensitivity surface emphasizes this point by shifting the focus from precision to range. Different combinations of near-term growth and long-term assumptions can justify the same valuation outcome. Pfizerâ€™s current valuation at almost $190bn EV sits closer to the conservative end of that landscape, reflecting restrained expectations for durability rather than skepticism about the underlying business.

Iso-valuation curves further highlight the trade-offs involved. Slower near-term growth can be offset by stronger long-term persistence, and vice versa. What matters is the combination of assumptions, not any single input.

 

Seen through this lens, Pfizerâ€™s valuation reflects a market that is cautious about long-term convergence rather than skeptical of near-term economics.

Analyst Positioning Signals Patience, Not Negativity

Consensus analyst ratings reinforce this interpretation. A prevalence of â€œHoldâ€ recommendations suggests caution rather than bearish conviction. The market appears to be waiting for clearer evidence on execution and durability before adjusting long-term expectations.

 

This positioning aligns with a company viewed as fundamentally sound, yet operating in an environment where confidence is rebuilt gradually.

Market Prices vs. Modeled Value

Comparing Pfizerâ€™s historical share price with a model-implied value derived in early 2025 helps connect theory with market behavior. The modeled value serves as a stable reference point, while the actual share price fluctuates above and below it.

 

This comparison highlights an important distinction: valuation models estimate economic value, not the path markets take to reach it. Deviations reflect sentiment, timing, and confidence rather than immediate changes in intrinsic worth.

The divergence observed into late 2025 underscores how markets often require tangible proof of recovery and durability before re-rating, even when valuation frameworks remain intact.

The gaps between market price and modeled value are best viewed as expressions of risk perception. Periods below the valuation anchor correspond to elevated uncertainty and higher discount rates, not necessarily to impaired fundamentals.

From this perspective, Pfizerâ€™s valuation reflects a cautious, evidence-driven market â€” not a rejection of long-term potential.

Bringing the Story Together

Taken together, this bottom-up analysis suggests that Pfizerâ€™s valuation reflects complexity, long cycles, and conservative market expectations rather than a simple judgment on quality or strategy.

The appearance of undervaluation does not stem from a single mispricing, but from how markets process uncertainty, time, and execution risk. As these uncertainties resolve, valuation is likely to evolve gradually rather than abruptly.

This framework does not argue for an immediate re-rating or a specific price target. Instead, it offers a disciplined way to understand how business fundamentals, strategic decisions, and market psychology interact over time.

In that sense, valuation is not the conclusion of the analysis â€” it is the lens through which Pfizerâ€™s broader business story is reflected. We plan to revisit this framework once full 2025 financial results become available.

entry.title: move desktop based crystal runtime RPT rendering to cloud???
entry.content:
Background on Our Setup

Historically, our ERP application has been a thick-client desktop app, where the Crystal Reports runtime runs locally on each user's PC. This works well because Crystal can directly access the SQL Server database without issues.

We're now transitioning the ERP to a fully cloud-based, browser-accessible platform. In this new architecture, the browser client can't run the Crystal runtime locally, forcing us to shift report rendering to the server sideâ€”which is where the performance bottlenecks are appearing.

We're looking for real-world advice on viable paths forward and want to avoid costly dead ends during this modernization.

Key Questions for the Community

  • Have you successfully moved Crystal Reports to a server-side or cloud-hosted model to support web/browser-based clients? If so, what approach did you use (e.g., SAP Crystal Server on a VM, custom microservices, etc.)?
  • Did you adopt a hybrid approach, keeping some reports in Crystal while migrating others to different tools?
  • What major challenges did you encounter with performance, report scheduling, licensing, or security when moving away from client-side rendering?

We're not expecting a seamless "lift-and-shift" solutionâ€”just practical insights to guide our decisions as we update the platform.

Thanks for any experiences or recommendations you can share!

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Mandatory Serial Number Verification in Public Cloud RF
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

This is a know limitation in the RF system, we don't have a configuration to resolve it like the one to decide only the validation to, for example source bin, batch, and quantity as per the configuration activity (SSCUI) Define Warehouse-Specific Verification Determination. 

However, Adapting UIs for classic applications with Screen Personas allows you to adjust only screen elements that are displayed on a screen when the screen is being used. If some of the elements or screens are not displayed based on context (for example, serial numbers), you can't adjust these elements. Consequently, if you want to influence serial number fields, you must work with a serialized product. To overcome this limitation, you can use design mode on a desktop to adjust RF screens more easily. With design mode, you can see all the RF screens in your current presentation format (portrait or landscape) and all possible fields that belong to the RF transaction, without needing to prepare the necessary data upfront.

Please check the document about the Screen Personas below on topic 5.2 "RF Design Mode" for further information and if could help on your requirement:

ScreenPersonas_RF_EWM_S4H_Cloud

Best regards,

SAP Support.

entry.title: Stock & Quality Management by Handling Unit (Bags / Pallets) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I am currently working on an implementation of SAP S/4HANA Cloud â€“ Public Edition, and I have some questions regarding stock management and quality inspection at Handling Unit (HU) level.

1. Stock visibility by Handling Unit (Bags / Pallets)

I am not asking about HU tracking itself (creation, movement, or identification of HUs), but rather about stock visibility and inventory from a business point of view.

My questions are:

  • Is it possible in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to:

    • See how many bags of a specific material are available in stock?

    • See how many pallets of a material exist in stock?

  • Can we perform inventory counting based on Handling Units (for example: inventory by pallet or by bag), instead of only quantity in base unit of measure?

In other words, can we use Handling Units as a stock analysis and inventory dimension, not only as a logistical object?

2. Quality Management by Handling Unit

In addition, I would like to know if Quality Inspection by Handling Unit is supported in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition:

  • Is it possible to perform quality inspection at HU level (for example: inspection per pallet or per bag)?

  • Can inspection lots, results, or usage decisions be managed per Handling Unit, and not only at material / batch level?

From my understanding so far, Quality Management in Public Cloud seems to be mainly material- and batch-based, but I would like to confirm whether there are standard capabilities, configuration options, or known limitations regarding HU-based quality control.

3. Standard vs Limitations

If these scenarios are not supported, I would highly appreciate:

  • Confirmation of the limitation in Public Cloud

  • Any recommended workaround 

  • Clarification if this is supported only in Private Cloud / On-Premise

Thank you in advance for your support and insights.

Best regards,

entry.title: Reacting to missing documents, DYNPRO_FIELD_CONVERSION and other inconsistencies for MM invoices
entry.content:
Hello everyone, I'm glad to share that my Guided Answers page was published today!

It's basically a deeper version of the content from KBA 3116897.

While the KBA already provides the reports that should be followed to address the main inconsistencies in the MM-IV scope, sometimes the steps to run the reports are not clear. Many customers open cases in SAP can actually find the reports, but fail to run them because of some tricky steps that are expected from customer side.

Some reports need specific values in input fields, some others need previous report installation and execution before SAP can carry out with database fixes, some others require manual steps.

For that reason, the Guided Answers page explains the correct approach in detail for each scenario involving inconsistencies.

Those details are now explained in a user-friendly way, to allow customers to react to the inconsistencies promptly and create cases containing everything SAP needs to proceed to database corrections - only if necessary, because some cases can be directly corrected on customer side!

Here's the URL of the Guided Answers page (Consider bookmarking it - maybe you'll need it someday):
https://supportportal-sagaviewer.internal.cfapps.sap.hana.ondemand.com/#/tree/4015/actions/66701

entry.title: Re: RSBCS_REORG not deleting entries in SOST or rows in t...
entry.content:
RSBCS_REORG alone is often not sufficient to reduce entries in SOFFCONT1, especially for documents with status Sent or flagged as nonâ€‘deletable.

To clean up SOFFCONT1 / SOST effectively, SAP recommends executing a sequence of reports, not just one:

  1. RSSO_DELETE_PRIVATE
    â€“ Run for document classes RAW and OTF
    â€“ Deletes private SAPoffice documents

  2. RSSODFRE
    â€“ Frees orphaned SAPoffice documents

  3. RSBCS_REORG
    â€“ Again for document classes RAW and OTF

Relevant SAP Notes:

  • 966854 â€“ Reorganization â€“ New report

  • 1641830 â€“ Cleanup of undeletable BCS documents

  • 904711

Important points:

  • Entries with grey diamond status in SOST are usually already sent and may be referenced elsewhere.

  • SOFFCONT1 stores SAPoffice content (mail attachments, spool outputs, workflows, BCS messages).

  • To understand what is filling SOFFCONT1, analyze related tables SOOD / SOOS, which provide creator, creation date, and message type.

  • Table size at DB level will only shrink after a database reorganization, even if rows are deleted.

entry.title: Re: Which Document Area to use for a new repository on th...
entry.content:
For SOFFCONT1 / SAP Office / GOS attachments, the Document Area does not need to be maintained.

The Document Area in OAC0 is mainly relevant for SAP DMS (CV*) scenarios. When the repository is used for SAP Office content (SOFFCONT1, SOFFPHIO, GOS attachments, mails, etc.), SAP does not require a Document Area.

In practice:

  • You can leave the Document Area blank when creating the repository in OAC0

  • Assign the repository via a storage category (OACT)

  • Link document class SOFFPHIO to that storage category (SKPR08)

This setup is fully supported and commonly used when relocating SOFFCONT1 content to SAP Content Server / OpenText.

If you already have a repository with Document Area = Document Management System, it should not be reused for SOFFCONT1. A separate repository without Document Area is the recommended approach.

So yes â€” leaving Document Area empty is correct and supported for SOFFCONT1 use cases.

entry.title: Re: Workflow exploding SOFFCONT1 - what to do?
entry.content:
SOFFCONT1 growth in workflow scenarios is usually caused by workflow mails and attachments created by WFâ€‘BATCH, which are stored in soâ€‘called dark folders.

Deleting mails from inbox/outbox (RSSO_PRIVATE_DELETE / RSSORE00) is not sufficient, because workflow items are not userâ€‘owned.

To reduce SOFFCONT1 size, execute the cleanup reports in the correct sequence:

  1. RSSODLWF â€“ deletes workflowâ€‘related SAP Office documents (WFâ€‘BATCH)

  2. RSSODFRE â€“ frees orphaned SAP Office objects

  3. RSBCS_REORG â€“ reorganizes remaining SAP Office data

Run these reports for document classes RAW and OTF, preferably first in test mode.

Also review SAP Notes 536414 and 966854, which explain workflow mail cleanup and SAP Office reorganization.

For longâ€‘term prevention, consider:

  • Reducing workflow email notifications

  • Routing attachments to an external content server (via OAC0 / OACT)

This approach has proven effective in controlling SOFFCONT1 growth caused by workflow notifications.

entry.title: Re: Does RSBCS_REORG program also deletes SOFFCONT1 data...
entry.content:
No, RSBCS_REORG does NOT delete content from the external archive server.

RSBCS_REORG is used to reorganize and delete SAP Office metadata (for example entries in SOST, SOC3, SOFM, SOOD, etc.) that are no longer needed.
When SOFFCONT1 content has already been migrated to an external content repository (ArchiveLink / Content Server):

  • RSBCS_REORG does not touch the physical documents stored in the archive server

  • It only cleans up SAP Office control and reference records

  • Archived attachments remain safe and accessible via their ArchiveLink references

So in your scenario:

  • You can safely run RSBCS_REORG to reduce entries in SOC3 / SOST / SOFM

  • It will not delete archived SOFFCONT1 content

  • Actual content deletion from the archive is governed by archive retention policies, not RSBCS_REORG

entry.title: Re: long2lob conversion of table SOFFCONT1 ends with ora-03113: end-of-file on communication channel
entry.content: ORAâ€‘03113 during LONG2LOB with DBMS_REDEFINITION is often triggered by underlying ORAâ€‘00600 errors. In such cases, SAP typically recommends opening an Oracle support ticket, as this is a database internal issue and not solvable at application level.

entry.title: Re: how to retrieve data from content repository
entry.content: RSIRPIRLâ€‘relocated SOFFCONT1 documents remain GOS documents. They can still be accessed via OAOR (Business Document Navigator) once the correct object type is known. Technically, retrieval works via: SRGBTBREL (link between business object and SAPoffice object) SO_OBJECT_GET_CONTENT to derive LOIO SOFFPHIO to resolve PHIO â†’ physical content in the external repository OAC3 / TOA** tables are not relevant for GOS documents.

entry.title: Re: Reports to determine sent mails per user in SOST
entry.content:
SAP provides a standard report for this requirement.

Use report RSSOSOSTSTAT (transaction SE38).

This report gives statistics on outbound SAP Office emails and allows you to analyze:

  • Number of sent emails

  • Userâ€‘wise (sender) distribution

  • Timeâ€‘based selection

  • Statusâ€‘based filtering (sent, error, etc.)

It works directly on SOST data and is suitable even when there are millions of records, avoiding the need to export SOST to Excel manually.

You can view detailed selection options by opening the report documentation in SE38.

entry.title: Re: Personas: How to display each employee's picture?
entry.content: ChatGPT? Gemini? Claude? Perplexity? ðŸ™‚

entry.title: Re: Lob segment Reorganization failure
entry.content: This is a classic SOFFCONT1 LOB reorganization issue. In Oracle, LOB reorg requires at least 2Ã— the LOB size as free space in the tablespace. Additionally, specific Oracle 11.2.0.3 SBP levels have known bugs impacting SOFFCONT1 reorg. Best practices are: Clean up obsolete SAPoffice data first (SAP Note 1634908) Ensure sufficient free space Prefer export/import via BRSPACE or upgrade to a fixed SBP Reorg failures here are usually space or Oracle bug related, not BRTOOLS itself.

entry.title: Re: Migration Monitor exits with error code 103
entry.content: This error is typical for very large SOFFCONT1 tables during export. R3load is limited to 256 data files per package. SAP Note 1922094 explains this clearly. Splitting the table into smaller packages or using the latest kernel/R3load version is the correct approach.

entry.title: Re: Content server - using RSIRPIRL - how to find PHIO cl...
entry.content:
In short: RSIRPIRL works at PHIO class level, not document type level.

  • SOFFCONT1 documents â†’ PHIO class SOFFPHIO, source category SOFFDB

  • BDS_CONT1 documents â†’ PHIO classes starting with BDS_* (e.g. BDS_DOC, BDS_IMAGE depending on usage)

Key concepts:

  • Repository (OAC0): Physical storage (Content Server)

  • Category (OACT): Logical routing to a repository

  • PHIO Class: Technical document handler (used by RSIRPIRL)

  • Document Type (OAC3): Only relevant for ArchiveLink, not for RSIRPIRL

SKPR08 is relevant only when you want new documents of a PHIO class to be stored in a specific category going forward.
It is not mandatory for RSIRPIRL migration itself.

RSIRPIRL cannot split documents by business document type (e.g. invoice vs PO).
Migration happens per PHIO class only.

For sizing, SOFFCONT1 and BDS_CONT1 table sizes (DB02 / HANA Studio) are the only reliable indicators before migration.

entry.title: Re: Content Repository Migration in mind ?
entry.content: Thanks for sharing this detailed overview of Content Repository Migration approaches. This post clearly explains when to use RSIRPIRL, Z_DOC_COPY, and Z_MIGRATE_ARCHIVELINK based on the application context (GOS, DMS, ArchiveLink, KPro). Very helpful for avoiding common mistakes like using a generic report for applicationâ€‘specific attachments. This will definitely help during planning and sizing for largeâ€‘scale migrations.

entry.title: Re: Document display from fb03 not possible
entry.content: This issue occurs because SOFFCONT1 was excluded during client copy, so the attachment content is missing. SOFFPHIO/SOFFOIO may exist, but without SOFFCONT1 the documents cannot be displayed. Transport is not recommended for a 50â€¯GB tableâ€”please restore SOFFCONT1 from backup or re-copy it using a system copy / exportâ€“import method.

entry.title: Re: how to retrieve data from content repository
entry.content:
When documents are relocated from SOFFCONT1 to an external Content Repository using RSIRPIRL, they are no longer accessed via ArchiveLink transactions (OAAD / OAOR).

These documents are SAPoffice / KPro documents, so they must be accessed through the original business object or SAPoffice, not directly from the repository.

Key points:

  • RSIRPIRL moves content physically and updates KPro metadata.

  • After relocation, SOFFCONT1 is empty, but metadata remains in:

    • SOFFPHIO

    • SOFFLOIO

    • SOC3 / SOOD

  • Verify that the storage category in SOFFPHIO has changed from SOFFDB to your target category.

  • End users can retrieve the documents only via the original transaction/object (e.g. GOS, attachment list), not via OAAD/OAOR.

  • OAAD/OAOR are relevant for ArchiveLink, not SAPoffice/KPro documents.

So, if the application linkage is intact, document access will continue transparently after relocation.

entry.title: Re: How to interpret SAP HANA DB table sizes definitions?
entry.content:
Explanation of DB02 table size metrics:

  • Estimated maximum memory consumption: Expected RAM usage when the table is fully loaded into memory (compressed, column-store).

  • Current memory consumption â€“ Main storage: Memory used by the main (merged, read-optimized) column store.

  • Current memory consumption â€“ Delta storage: Memory used by unmerged delta records (new/changed data).

  • Current total memory consumption: Main + Delta memory usage.

  • Size on disk: Physical persistence on disk (usually larger due to LOBs, history, and storage format).

Large differences (e.g., SOFFCONT1) are normal because LOB data is usually not fully loaded into memory.

entry.title: Re: Retreival of the Archived BCS (Buiness Communication...
entry.content:
There is no SAPâ€‘standard or SAPâ€‘supported procedure to restore archived BCS (SOFFCONT1) data from the SAP Content Server back into the SAP database.

Reports like RSIRPIRL are designed as a oneâ€‘way relocation from database to content repository to reduce DB growth. SAP does not provide any reverse report to reload content into SOFFCONT1.

Access to archived BCS data is expected to remain via the Content Server / SAPoffice framework, not by reinserting records into SOFFCONT1. Any attempt to bring data back would require custom development and is not recommended or supported by SAP, especially in S/4HANA due to HANA cost and data consistency risks.

entry.title: Re: Table to fetch the Title & the Address of the URL
entry.content:
For GOS â€œCreate external document (URL)â€, the Title is stored in SOOD.
The URL/address itself is stored in table SOC3 (field depending on SAP release), not in SOFFCONT1.
URLs and notes are handled as SAPoffice documents; only PC attachments may go to SOFFCONT1/KPro.
Refer to SAP Note 530792 for the exact storage behavior.

entry.title: Re: SOC3 and SOFFCOUNT1 Archiving
entry.content:
SOC3 data can be archived using standard SAP tools such as report RSSOAPUT (BCS archiving).
However, SOFFCONT1 does not support archiving via SAP Archive Development Kit. Entries can only be deleted/reorganized (for example using RSBCS_REORG or by relocating content to a content server via RSIRPIRL).
Always test thoroughly before executing in production.

entry.title: Re: Find were the actual attachment is stored in table.
entry.content:
SOC3 data can be archived using report RSSOAPUT (after proper testing).
SOFFCONT1 cannot be archived via SAP archiving objects; it can only be deleted/reorganized using RSBCS_REORG or relocated to a content server using RSIRPIRL.
SAP does not provide a standard archive object for SOFFCONT1.

entry.title: Re: Moivng contents of SOC3 table to Content server
entry.content:
SOC3 data cannot be migrated to a Content Server in the same way as SOFFCONT1.

SOFFCONT1 stores large binary content managed via KPro and can be relocated to a Content Server using RSIRPIRL.

SOC3 mainly contains small contents such as notes, URLs, and metadata, and is not designed for KPro-based content server relocation. SAP does not provide any standard tool or procedure to move SOC3 content to a Content Server.

The supported approach for SOC3 is SAP Office archiving/deletion, for example using report RSSOAPUT, after proper testing.

If SOC3 is growing significantly, review usage patterns and housekeeping rather than content server migration.

entry.title: Re: Regarding the SAP big tables in ECC 6.0
entry.content:
These are standard SAP tables that typically grow over time.
â€¢ TST03 â€“ Spool data; clean up using RSPO0041 / RSPO1041 and reorganize if oversized.
â€¢ COEP â€“ CO line items; reduce size via CO archiving objects in SARA.
â€¢ SOFFCONT1 â€“ SAP Office document content; reduce via reorganization/relocation (e.g. RSIRPIRL) and deletion policies.
â€¢ GLPCA â€“ PCA line items; archive using EC-PCA archiving objects.
â€¢ EDI40 â€“ IDoc data; delete/archive old IDocs (WE11 / SAP Note 40088).
Refer to the SAP Database Management Guide and relevant SAP Notes for prevention and cleanup.

entry.title: Re: After import table content is missing
entry.content: This is the correct approach for recovering SOFFCONT1 after an incomplete Unicode migration. Using R3load -merge_bck preserves newly created data and avoids overwriting active records. Important to validate dependencies and test carefully before production use.

entry.title: Re: Most allocated extents in any segment oracle 11g
entry.content:
For Oracle 11g with locally managed tablespaces, a high number of extents (even for LOB segments like SOFFCONT1) is not an issue because MAX_EXTENTS is UNLIMITED and extent sizes are managed automatically.
This CCMS alert is informational only. No action is required unless you see real space or performance problems.
Refer SAP Note 483856 for details.

entry.title: Re: How the project attachment file link to project?
entry.content:
In CJ20N, project attachments are linked via Generic Object Services (GOS) / BDS.
The relationship between the project (object type BUS2054 / PROJ) and attachments is stored in SRGBTBREL.
For SAPoffice attachments, document data is held in SOOD / SOFM / SOC3 / SOFFCONT1.

To retrieve attachments programmatically, use BDS_ALL_CONNECTIONS_GET (for BDS/ArchiveLink) or GOS APIs.
SAP Note 530792 explains the storage and linkage in detail.

entry.title: Re: Unknown objects in ABAP Dictionary
entry.content:
The unknown object SOFFCONT1#$ is a leftover from an interrupted BRSPACE table reorganization. It can be safely removed using:
brspace -f tbreorg -t SOFFCONT1#$ -a cleanup.

The SAP_AUXSTATS DB view belongs to DBA Cockpit/Oracle statistics and may appear as â€œunknownâ€ in older Basis releases. No manual action is recommendedâ€”open an SAP incident if the warning persists.

entry.title: Re: Content Server Table for REBDPR Tcode
entry.content: Attachments in REBDPR are handled via SAPoffice. SOFFLOIO / SOFFPHIO store the logical & physical document references, while the actual content is stored in SOFFCONT1 (or an external content server if configured). See SAP Note 904711 for full details. SQL/ABAP trace during upload can confirm the flow.

entry.title: Re: Reduce size LOBSEGMENT
entry.content: Deleting entries from SOFFCONT1 does not automatically shrink the associated LOB segment. For LOBs, space is not released unless the LOB is moved or rebuilt. You need to reorganize the LOB segment explicitly (e.g. BRSPACE LOB reorg or MOVE LOB), or relocate content to a content server (RSIRPIRL). Otherwise, the LOB size remaining large is expected behavior.

entry.title: Re: what is the procedure to transfer attached documents...
entry.content:
There is no supported way to transfer attachments by transporting SOFFCONT1. Attachments are part of SAPoffice/KPro and must be moved using standard relocation tools.

If attachments are stored in the database, use RSIRPIRL to relocate them to a Content Server. If they are already on a Content Server, configure the new repository (OAC0/OACT/SKPR08) and perform a content server migration using SAPâ€‘supported tools (repository copy or vendor tools like OpenText).

Transporting SOFFCONT1 is not recommended and can lead to inconsistencies.

entry.title: Re: Content Repository Migration in mind ? Part IV Error in Migration
entry.content: Thanks for the detailed explanation. For Content Repository migration errors, checking SLG1 logs (objects SDOK and SCMS) is crucial to identify whether the issue is at the source or target repository. Verifying the target repository with RSCMST / RSCMSTH0 before reruns also helps avoid partial or inconsistent migrations. This blog is very helpful for troubleshooting RSIRPIRL-related issues.

entry.title: Re: systemVars.dimensions.viewport.height malfunction
entry.content: Apparently, this issue appears on some devices e.g. on Android 16, while older devices, e.g. Android 11 work properly!

entry.title: Re: Archiving Emails in CRM
entry.content: Email archiving in CRM is not done via WORKITEM archiving alone. Attachments are stored in SOFFCONT1 and should be relocated using RSIRPIRL to a content server. Email body/text stored in SOC3 / SAPoffice can be archived via SOY8. WORKITEM archiving is only relevant if emails are processed via SAP Connect workflow. SAP Note 904711 gives a good overview.

entry.title: Re: Dynamic table name in Select * From (Table_name)
entry.content:
you can select the data but that won't help you at all,
because there is no dynamic data target.

entry.title: Re: Row Compression in db2 9.7
entry.content: TST03 growth is mainly driven by LOB data, so DB2 row compression has limited effect. Best approach is housekeeping as per SAP Note 48400 or increasing INLINE LENGTH for the LOB. For SOFFCONT1, moving content to an external repository is recommended.

entry.title: TMS External Planning via CPI
entry.content:
There are many situations where a TMS application must connect with external or 3rdâ€‘party systems such as JDE, MercuryGate, or legacy homeâ€‘grown applications. These integrations are typically implemented to exchange transportation data, automate business transactions, and maintain end-to-end visibility across the supply chain.

 

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/e3dc5400c1cc41d1bc0ae0e7fd9aa5a2/5505d7ffe42c496788d504e54ce80e59.html?locale=en-US

In a typical SAP TM landscape, standard SAP integration enables the system to send Freight Units (FUs) to an external or 3rdâ€‘party Transportation Management application (such as JDE, MercuryGate, or a legacy system) without requiring any custom development.

The standard process works as follows:

  1. SAP TM creates Freight Units (FUs) based on sales orders, purchase orders, or deliveries.
  2. These FUs are sent to the 3rdâ€‘party TMS using SAPâ€™s outâ€‘ofâ€‘theâ€‘box integration capabilities ( CPI,).
  3. The external TMS performs:
    • Load planning
    • Carrier selection
    • Routing
    • Tendering
  4. The 3rdâ€‘party system then sends routing and carrier assignment confirmation back to SAP TM using the standard interface.
  5. SAP TM automatically:
    • Creates a Freight Order (FO) based on the received planning data
    • Links the FO to the original Freight Unit
    • Consumes the FU (i.e., the FU becomes assigned to the FO)

All of this is supported by SAPâ€™s standard integration content, which means no custom development is required for core message flows or planning confirmation processing.

Configuration Steps : 

1. Enable the PPF action : TOR_TPNOR_FU at FU level using 

2. Activate the services in SICF 

3. Check the SRT_ADMIN report for Webservice and Task Watcher readiness (SAP support team help need to run the SRT_ADMIN in 000 client via serivce ticket)

4. Create SOAP endpoint in CPI

5. Expose/obtain the WSDL for that endpoint (from CPI).

6. Create Logical Port in SOAMANAGER for your DEV  unit test client

 How to Test : 

Hereâ€™s a clean, stepâ€‘byâ€‘step way to Generate a Freight Unit (FU) in SAP TM and verify that the PPF action triggers successfully and XML is generated for outbound integration â€” exactly what you'd check during FU â†’ 3rdâ€‘party integration testing.

For any errors , please check the tcode SRT_UTIL 

Summary : 

1. S/4 to External Planning system : TransportationOrderGenericRequest_Out

2. External Planning System to S/4 : TransportationOrderGenericRequest_In

If you want to receive charges from the external planning system, you must use the additional web service TransportationOrderChargeElementRequest_In, as charge transfers are not covered by the standard inbound service TransportationOrderGenericRequest_In.

 
Would like to share my findings with SAP community!

Thank you
Hari Sivvala

entry.title: Re: where is the attached file stored in ECC6.0?
entry.content:
In ECC 6.0, attachments (texts, screenshots, files) are typically stored in table SOFFCONT1 (content), with metadata in SOOD / SOFM.
There is no fixed SAP limit, but large attachments increase database size, so SAP recommends moving them to a Content Server

entry.title: Re: Optimizing DMO Process During SAP S/4HANA Conversion
entry.content: Great blog! Very practical insights on DMO downtime optimization. The realâ€‘world use of the Downtime Optimization App and manual table splitting (especially SOFFCONT1) is extremely helpful for large S/4HANA conversions. Thanks for sharing your experience.

entry.title: Re: Unable to delete unused material number ranges predelivered by SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition

entry.title: Re: We have setup bank account to All currencies. And wan...
entry.content: If you mean house bank accounts, the currency is not defined by the bank account itself, but rather by GL account that is set for this bank. So if you want to change to a single currency, create new GL account with that currency and set this GL account on your bank account.
